procedures.name: Total Hip Arthroplasty
procedures.description: Total hip replacement surgery

primaryProphylaxis.dose: 2 g IV (3 g if weight ≥120 kg)
primaryProphylaxis.redosingInterval: Redose every 4 hours if procedure continues
primaryProphylaxis.rationale: First-line prophylaxis for clean orthopedic procedures with excellent MSSA coverage
warnings: Ensure complete infusion before tourniquet inflation
monitoring: Assess surgical site for signs of infection

betaLactamAllergyAlternative.dose: 15 mg/kg IV (max 2 g)
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.timing: Within 120 minutes before incision (infuse over 1-2 hours)
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.redosingInterval: Redose every 6 hours if procedure continues
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.rationale: Alternative for beta-lactam allergy with MRSA coverage
warnings: Slow infusion to prevent red man syndrome

mrsaCoverageAddition.dose: Vancomycin 15 mg/kg IV + Cefazolin 2 g IV
mrsaCoverageAddition.timing: Vancomycin 120 min before, Cefazolin 60 min before incision
mrsaCoverageAddition.redosingInterval: Redose per individual agent guidelines
mrsaCoverageAddition.rationale: Add vancomycin for known MRSA colonization or high institutional MRSA rates

specialConsiderations: Consider vancomycin addition if MRSA colonization or high institutional rates (>10%)
Ensure antibiotic infusion complete before tourniquet inflation
Redose if procedure >4 hours or blood loss >1500 mL
Discontinue prophylaxis within 24 hours post-operatively

procedures.name: Total Knee Arthroplasty
procedures.description: Total knee replacement surgery

primaryProphylaxis.dose: 2 g IV (3 g if weight ≥120 kg)
primaryProphylaxis.redosingInterval: Redose every 4 hours if procedure continues
primaryProphylaxis.rationale: First-line prophylaxis for clean orthopedic procedures
warnings: Ensure complete infusion before tourniquet inflation
monitoring: Assess surgical site for signs of infection

betaLactamAllergyAlternative.dose: 15 mg/kg IV (max 2 g)
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.timing: Within 120 minutes before incision (infuse over 1-2 hours)
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.redosingInterval: Redose every 6 hours if procedure continues
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.rationale: Alternative for beta-lactam allergy
warnings: Slow infusion to prevent red man syndrome

mrsaCoverageAddition.dose: Vancomycin 15 mg/kg IV + Cefazolin 2 g IV
mrsaCoverageAddition.timing: Vancomycin 120 min before, Cefazolin 60 min before incision
mrsaCoverageAddition.redosingInterval: Redose per individual agent guidelines
mrsaCoverageAddition.rationale: Add vancomycin for known MRSA colonization

specialConsiderations: Same considerations as total hip arthroplasty
Tourniquet timing critical for antibiotic tissue levels
Consider patient-specific risk factors (diabetes, obesity, immunosuppression)

procedures.name: CABG / Cardiac Surgery
procedures.description: Coronary artery bypass graft and valve surgery

primaryProphylaxis.dose: 2 g IV (3 g if weight ≥120 kg)
primaryProphylaxis.redosingInterval: Redose every 4 hours during procedure
primaryProphylaxis.rationale: Standard prophylaxis for cardiac surgery with extended duration

betaLactamAllergyAlternative.dose: 15 mg/kg IV (max 2 g)
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.redosingInterval: Redose every 6 hours during procedure
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.rationale: Alternative for beta-lactam allergy

mrsaCoverageAddition.dose: Vancomycin 15 mg/kg IV + Cefazolin 2 g IV
mrsaCoverageAddition.timing: Vancomycin 120 min before, Cefazolin 60 min before incision
mrsaCoverageAddition.redosingInterval: Redose per individual agent guidelines

specialConsiderations: Redose after cardiopulmonary bypass due to hemodilution
Extended duration (48 hours) for cardiac surgery
High risk for mediastinitis - strict adherence to timing
Consider vancomycin for MRSA colonization or high institutional rates

procedures.name: Colorectal Surgery
procedures.description: Elective colorectal resection

primaryProphylaxis.dose: Cefoxitin 2 g IV OR Cefazolin 2 g + Metronidazole 500 mg IV
primaryProphylaxis.redosingInterval: Cefoxitin: every 2 hours; Cefazolin: every 4 hours
primaryProphylaxis.rationale: Coverage for aerobic and anaerobic colonic flora
warnings: Mechanical bowel prep no longer routinely recommended

betaLactamAllergyAlternative.dose: Clindamycin 900 mg + Gentamicin 5 mg/kg IV OR Ciprofloxacin 400 mg + Metronidazole 500 mg IV
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.redosingInterval: Clindamycin: every 6 hours; Gentamicin: single dose
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.rationale: Non-beta-lactam alternative with aerobic and anaerobic coverage

specialConsiderations: Oral antibiotic bowel prep may be added (neomycin + metronidazole)
Mechanical bowel prep alone not recommended
Redosing critical for prolonged procedures
Discontinue within 24 hours to reduce C. difficile risk

procedures.name: Cesarean Section
procedures.description: Cesarean delivery

primaryProphylaxis.dose: 2 g IV (3 g if weight ≥120 kg)
primaryProphylaxis.redosingInterval: Redose every 4 hours if procedure continues
primaryProphylaxis.rationale: Reduces post-cesarean endometritis and wound infection
warnings: Administer before skin incision (not after cord clamping)

betaLactamAllergyAlternative.dose: Clindamycin 900 mg + Gentamicin 5 mg/kg IV
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.redosingInterval: Clindamycin: every 6 hours if needed
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.rationale: Alternative for beta-lactam allergy

specialConsiderations: Administer before skin incision (updated from after cord clamping)
Higher dose (3 g) for patients ≥120 kg
Single dose sufficient for most cases
Extended spectrum not needed for routine cesarean

references.label: WHO Recommendations for Prevention of Maternal Peripartum Infections

procedures.name: Hysterectomy (Abdominal/Vaginal)
procedures.description: Abdominal or vaginal hysterectomy

primaryProphylaxis.dose: Cefazolin 2 g IV OR Cefoxitin 2 g IV
primaryProphylaxis.redosingInterval: Cefazolin: every 4 hours; Cefoxitin: every 2 hours
primaryProphylaxis.rationale: Prophylaxis against vaginal flora

betaLactamAllergyAlternative.dose: Clindamycin 900 mg + Gentamicin 5 mg/kg IV
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.redosingInterval: Clindamycin: every 6 hours if needed
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.rationale: Non-beta-lactam alternative

specialConsiderations: Vaginal approach has higher infection risk than abdominal
Single dose adequate for most cases
Extended prophylaxis not recommended

procedures.name: Appendectomy
procedures.description: Appendectomy for non-perforated appendicitis

primaryProphylaxis.dose: Cefoxitin 2 g IV OR Cefazolin 2 g + Metronidazole 500 mg IV
primaryProphylaxis.duration: Single dose for non-perforated; therapeutic for perforated
primaryProphylaxis.redosingInterval: Cefoxitin: every 2 hours if procedure continues
primaryProphylaxis.rationale: Coverage for enteric aerobic and anaerobic organisms
warnings: If perforated, convert to therapeutic antibiotics (4-7 days)
Single dose only for non-perforated appendicitis

betaLactamAllergyAlternative.dose: Ciprofloxacin 400 mg + Metronidazole 500 mg IV
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.redosingInterval: Every 12 hours if therapeutic course needed
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.rationale: Non-beta-lactam alternative

specialConsiderations: Distinguish prophylaxis (non-perforated) from treatment (perforated)
If perforated: 4-7 days therapeutic antibiotics
Laparoscopic vs open approach - same prophylaxis

procedures.name: Inguinal/Ventral Hernia Repair (Clean)
procedures.description: Elective hernia repair with mesh placement

primaryProphylaxis.dose: 2 g IV (3 g if weight ≥120 kg)
primaryProphylaxis.redosingInterval: Redose every 4 hours if procedure continues
primaryProphylaxis.rationale: Prophylaxis recommended for mesh placement to prevent surgical site infection
warnings: Single dose sufficient for clean hernia repair
monitoring: Monitor surgical site for signs of infection

betaLactamAllergyAlternative.dose: 900 mg IV
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.redosingInterval: Redose every 6 hours if procedure continues
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.rationale: Alternative for beta-lactam allergy with gram-positive coverage

mrsaCoverageAddition.dose: 15 mg/kg IV (max 2 g)
mrsaCoverageAddition.timing: Within 120 minutes before incision
mrsaCoverageAddition.redosingInterval: Redose every 6 hours if procedure continues

specialConsiderations: Mesh placement increases infection risk - prophylaxis recommended
Clean hernia repair without mesh: prophylaxis optional
Recurrent hernia or previous infection: consider extended prophylaxis
Laparoscopic vs open: same prophylaxis regimen

procedures.name: Breast Surgery (Lumpectomy/Mastectomy)
procedures.description: Breast cancer surgery including lumpectomy, mastectomy, and reconstruction

primaryProphylaxis.dose: 2 g IV (3 g if weight ≥120 kg)
primaryProphylaxis.redosingInterval: Redose every 4 hours if procedure continues
primaryProphylaxis.rationale: Reduces surgical site infection risk, especially with reconstruction or implant placement
warnings: Consider extended prophylaxis for immediate reconstruction
monitoring: Monitor surgical site and drain sites
Assess for signs of cellulitis or abscess

betaLactamAllergyAlternative.dose: 900 mg IV
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.redosingInterval: Redose every 6 hours if procedure continues
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.rationale: Alternative for beta-lactam allergy

mrsaCoverageAddition.dose: 15 mg/kg IV (max 2 g)
mrsaCoverageAddition.timing: Within 120 minutes before incision
mrsaCoverageAddition.redosingInterval: Redose every 6 hours if procedure continues
mrsaCoverageAddition.rationale: MRSA coverage for colonized patients or high-risk settings
warnings: Slow infusion to prevent red man syndrome

specialConsiderations: Implant/expander placement: prophylaxis strongly recommended
Simple lumpectomy without reconstruction: prophylaxis optional
Immediate reconstruction: consider 24-hour prophylaxis
Neoadjuvant chemotherapy: may increase infection risk

procedures.name: Craniotomy (Clean Neurosurgery)
procedures.description: Cranial surgery including tumor resection, aneurysm clipping, and other clean neurosurgical procedures

primaryProphylaxis.dose: 2 g IV (3 g if weight ≥120 kg)
primaryProphylaxis.redosingInterval: Redose every 4 hours if procedure continues
primaryProphylaxis.rationale: Reduces risk of surgical site infection and meningitis in clean neurosurgical procedures
warnings: Consider vancomycin addition for shunt procedures
monitoring: Assess surgical site for CSF leak or infection

betaLactamAllergyAlternative.dose: 15 mg/kg IV (max 2 g)
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.timing: Within 120 minutes before incision (infuse over 1-2 hours)
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.redosingInterval: Redose every 6 hours if procedure continues
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.rationale: Alternative for beta-lactam allergy with good CNS penetration

mrsaCoverageAddition.dose: Vancomycin 15 mg/kg IV + Cefazolin 2 g IV
mrsaCoverageAddition.timing: Vancomycin within 120 minutes, Cefazolin within 60 minutes before incision
mrsaCoverageAddition.redosingInterval: Vancomycin every 6 hours, Cefazolin every 4 hours
mrsaCoverageAddition.rationale: Dual coverage for MRSA colonization or high-risk patients
monitoring: Monitor for adverse reactions to both agents

specialConsiderations: CSF shunt procedures: consider vancomycin addition
Prolonged procedures (>4 hours): ensure redosing
Previous neurosurgical infection: consider extended prophylaxis
Implanted devices (plates, mesh): increases infection risk

procedures.name: Spinal Surgery (Laminectomy/Fusion)
procedures.description: Spinal procedures including laminectomy, discectomy, and spinal fusion with or without instrumentation

primaryProphylaxis.dose: 2 g IV (3 g if weight ≥120 kg)
primaryProphylaxis.duration: Single dose (24 hours maximum for instrumented fusion)
primaryProphylaxis.redosingInterval: Redose every 4 hours if procedure continues
primaryProphylaxis.rationale: Prevents surgical site infection, especially important for instrumented procedures
monitoring: Assess for signs of discitis or osteomyelitis

betaLactamAllergyAlternative.dose: 15 mg/kg IV (max 2 g)
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.duration: Single dose (24 hours maximum for instrumented fusion)
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.redosingInterval: Redose every 6 hours if procedure continues
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.rationale: Alternative for beta-lactam allergy

mrsaCoverageAddition.dose: Vancomycin 15 mg/kg IV + Cefazolin 2 g IV
mrsaCoverageAddition.timing: Vancomycin within 120 minutes, Cefazolin within 60 minutes before incision
mrsaCoverageAddition.duration: Single dose (24 hours maximum for instrumented fusion)
mrsaCoverageAddition.redosingInterval: Vancomycin every 6 hours, Cefazolin every 4 hours

specialConsiderations: Instrumented fusion: consider 24-hour prophylaxis
Simple discectomy: single dose sufficient
Revision surgery: higher infection risk
Obesity: ensure adequate dosing (3 g cefazolin if ≥120 kg)

procedures.name: Vascular Surgery (Arterial Reconstruction)
procedures.description: Arterial reconstruction including aortic aneurysm repair, peripheral bypass, and carotid endarterectomy

primaryProphylaxis.dose: 2 g IV (3 g if weight ≥120 kg)
primaryProphylaxis.redosingInterval: Redose every 4 hours if procedure continues
primaryProphylaxis.rationale: Prevents graft infection and surgical site infection in vascular procedures
warnings: Graft infection is catastrophic - ensure adequate prophylaxis
Redose for prolonged procedures or significant blood loss
monitoring: Monitor graft site for signs of infection
Assess for graft thrombosis or pseudoaneurysm

betaLactamAllergyAlternative.dose: 15 mg/kg IV (max 2 g)
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.redosingInterval: Redose every 6 hours if procedure continues
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.rationale: Alternative for beta-lactam allergy with gram-positive coverage
warnings: No gram-negative coverage - consider adding aztreonam for groin incisions

mrsaCoverageAddition.dose: Vancomycin 15 mg/kg IV + Cefazolin 2 g IV
mrsaCoverageAddition.timing: Vancomycin within 120 minutes, Cefazolin within 60 minutes before incision
mrsaCoverageAddition.redosingInterval: Vancomycin every 6 hours, Cefazolin every 4 hours
mrsaCoverageAddition.rationale: Dual coverage for MRSA colonization or high-risk patients

specialConsiderations: Prosthetic graft: consider 24-hour prophylaxis
Groin incision: higher infection risk
Lower extremity bypass: consider gram-negative coverage
Carotid endarterectomy: single dose sufficient

procedures.name: Prostatectomy (Radical/Simple)
procedures.description: Radical or simple prostatectomy for cancer or benign prostatic hyperplasia

primaryProphylaxis.dose: 2 g IV (3 g if weight ≥120 kg)
primaryProphylaxis.redosingInterval: Redose every 4 hours if procedure continues
primaryProphylaxis.rationale: Prevents urinary tract infection and surgical site infection
warnings: Treat active UTI before elective surgery

betaLactamAllergyAlternative.dose: Ciprofloxacin 400 mg IV or Levofloxacin 500 mg IV
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.redosingInterval: Ciprofloxacin every 12 hours, Levofloxacin every 24 hours
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.rationale: Alternative with excellent urinary tract penetration

mrsaCoverageAddition.dose: Vancomycin 15 mg/kg IV + Cefazolin 2 g IV
mrsaCoverageAddition.timing: Vancomycin within 120 minutes, Cefazolin within 60 minutes before incision
mrsaCoverageAddition.redosingInterval: Vancomycin every 6 hours, Cefazolin every 4 hours

specialConsiderations: Preoperative urine culture mandatory
Treat active UTI before elective surgery
Catheter removal as soon as possible postoperatively
Robotic vs open: same prophylaxis regimen

procedures.name: Cholecystectomy (Laparoscopic/Open)
procedures.description: Gallbladder removal for cholecystitis, cholelithiasis, or biliary dyskinesia

primaryProphylaxis.dose: 2 g IV (3 g if weight ≥120 kg)
primaryProphylaxis.duration: Single dose (no postoperative doses for uncomplicated cases)
primaryProphylaxis.redosingInterval: Redose every 4 hours if procedure continues
primaryProphylaxis.rationale: Prophylaxis recommended for high-risk patients (age >60, acute cholecystitis, diabetes, immunosuppression)
warnings: If bile spillage: consider therapeutic antibiotics
monitoring: Assess for bile leak or abscess

betaLactamAllergyAlternative.dose: Ciprofloxacin 400 mg IV + Metronidazole 500 mg IV
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.redosingInterval: Ciprofloxacin every 12 hours, Metronidazole every 8 hours
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.rationale: Alternative with gram-negative and anaerobic coverage

mrsaCoverageAddition.dose: Vancomycin 15 mg/kg IV + Cefazolin 2 g IV
mrsaCoverageAddition.timing: Vancomycin within 120 minutes, Cefazolin within 60 minutes before incision
mrsaCoverageAddition.redosingInterval: Vancomycin every 6 hours, Cefazolin every 4 hours

specialConsiderations: High-risk factors: age >60, acute cholecystitis, diabetes, immunosuppression, jaundice
Low-risk elective: prophylaxis optional
Conversion to open: no additional antibiotics needed
Bile spillage: consider therapeutic course if contamination significant

references.label: Tokyo Guidelines for Acute Cholangitis and Cholecystitis 2024

procedures.name: Thyroidectomy (Total/Partial)
procedures.description: Thyroid gland removal for cancer, goiter, or hyperthyroidism

primaryProphylaxis.dose: N/A
primaryProphylaxis.rationale: Clean procedure with low infection risk - routine prophylaxis not recommended per 2024 guidelines
warnings: Prophylaxis only for high-risk patients (immunosuppression, diabetes, previous neck surgery)
If prophylaxis indicated: Cefazolin 2 g IV single dose

betaLactamAllergyAlternative.dose: 900 mg IV

mrsaCoverageAddition.dose: 15 mg/kg IV (max 2 g)
mrsaCoverageAddition.timing: Within 120 minutes before incision
mrsaCoverageAddition.rationale: MRSA coverage for colonized high-risk patients

specialConsiderations: Routine prophylaxis NOT recommended for standard thyroidectomy
High-risk patients: immunosuppression, diabetes, previous neck surgery, radiation
Sternotomy or mediastinal dissection: consider prophylaxis
Low infection rate (<1%) in clean thyroid surgery

procedures.name: Gastric Surgery (Gastrectomy/Bariatric)
procedures.description: Gastric procedures including gastrectomy for cancer, gastric bypass, and sleeve gastrectomy

primaryProphylaxis.dose: 2 g IV (3 g if weight ≥120 kg)
primaryProphylaxis.redosingInterval: Redose every 4 hours if procedure continues
primaryProphylaxis.rationale: Prevents surgical site infection in gastric procedures with high bacterial load
warnings: Bariatric surgery: ensure adequate dosing for obesity (3 g if ≥120 kg)
Redose for prolonged procedures or blood loss >1500 mL
Consider PPI discontinuation preoperatively to reduce infection risk

betaLactamAllergyAlternative.dose: Ciprofloxacin 400 mg IV + Metronidazole 500 mg IV
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.redosingInterval: Ciprofloxacin every 12 hours, Metronidazole every 8 hours
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.rationale: Alternative with broad-spectrum coverage

mrsaCoverageAddition.dose: Vancomycin 15 mg/kg IV + Cefazolin 2-3 g IV
mrsaCoverageAddition.timing: Vancomycin within 120 minutes, Cefazolin within 60 minutes before incision
mrsaCoverageAddition.redosingInterval: Vancomycin every 6 hours, Cefazolin every 4 hours

specialConsiderations: Bariatric surgery: weight-based dosing critical (3 g cefazolin if ≥120 kg)
Gastric cancer surgery: consider extended prophylaxis for complex resections
PPI use: may increase infection risk - consider discontinuation preoperatively
Anastomotic leak: most serious complication - ensure adequate prophylaxis

procedures.name: Nephrectomy (Partial/Radical)
procedures.description: Kidney removal for cancer, donation, or non-functioning kidney

primaryProphylaxis.dose: 2 g IV (3 g if weight ≥120 kg)
primaryProphylaxis.redosingInterval: Redose every 4 hours if procedure continues
primaryProphylaxis.rationale: Prevents urinary tract infection and surgical site infection
warnings: Treat active UTI before elective surgery
Collecting system entry: increases infection risk

betaLactamAllergyAlternative.dose: Ciprofloxacin 400 mg IV or Levofloxacin 500 mg IV
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.redosingInterval: Ciprofloxacin every 12 hours, Levofloxacin every 24 hours
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.rationale: Alternative with excellent urinary tract penetration

mrsaCoverageAddition.dose: Vancomycin 15 mg/kg IV + Cefazolin 2 g IV
mrsaCoverageAddition.timing: Vancomycin within 120 minutes, Cefazolin within 60 minutes before incision
mrsaCoverageAddition.redosingInterval: Vancomycin every 6 hours, Cefazolin every 4 hours

specialConsiderations: Preoperative urine culture mandatory
Treat active UTI before elective surgery
Collecting system entry: higher infection risk
Robotic vs open vs laparoscopic: same prophylaxis regimen
Living donor nephrectomy: single dose sufficient

procedures.name: Cystectomy (Radical with Urinary Diversion)
procedures.description: Bladder removal with urinary diversion for bladder cancer

primaryProphylaxis.dose: Cefazolin 2 g IV (3 g if ≥120 kg) + Metronidazole 500 mg IV
primaryProphylaxis.redosingInterval: Cefazolin every 4 hours, Metronidazole every 8 hours
primaryProphylaxis.rationale: Broad-spectrum coverage for complex procedure involving bowel manipulation
warnings: Bowel preparation: mechanical prep + oral antibiotics recommended
High infection risk due to bowel manipulation
monitoring: Assess for intra-abdominal abscess or anastomotic leak

betaLactamAllergyAlternative.dose: Ciprofloxacin 400 mg IV + Metronidazole 500 mg IV
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.redosingInterval: Ciprofloxacin every 12 hours, Metronidazole every 8 hours
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.rationale: Alternative with broad-spectrum coverage

mrsaCoverageAddition.dose: Vancomycin 15 mg/kg IV + Cefazolin 2 g IV + Metronidazole 500 mg IV
mrsaCoverageAddition.timing: Vancomycin within 120 minutes, others within 60 minutes before incision
mrsaCoverageAddition.redosingInterval: Vancomycin every 6 hours, Cefazolin every 4 hours, Metronidazole every 8 hours
warnings: Coordinate timing of all three antibiotics

specialConsiderations: Bowel preparation: mechanical prep + oral antibiotics (neomycin + metronidazole)
Prolonged procedure (4-8 hours): ensure redosing
Urinary diversion type: ileal conduit vs neobladder - same prophylaxis
High infection risk: meticulous surgical technique critical

procedures.name: Perforated Appendicitis (Contaminated)
procedures.description: Appendectomy with perforation and peritoneal contamination

primaryProphylaxis.dose: Piperacillin-Tazobactam 3.375 g IV or Cefepime 2 g IV + Metronidazole 500 mg IV
primaryProphylaxis.redosingInterval: Piperacillin-Tazobactam every 6 hours, Cefepime every 8 hours, Metronidazole every 8 hours
primaryProphylaxis.rationale: Therapeutic antibiotics required for established intra-abdominal infection with peritoneal contamination
warnings: This is therapeutic treatment, not prophylaxis
Adjust duration based on clinical response
Consider imaging if no improvement by day 3-4
monitoring: Monitor for clinical improvement (fever, WBC, abdominal exam)
Consider CT if persistent fever or leukocytosis

betaLactamAllergyAlternative.dose: Ciprofloxacin 400 mg IV every 12 hours + Metronidazole 500 mg IV every 8 hours
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.redosingInterval: Ciprofloxacin every 12 hours, Metronidazole every 8 hours
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.rationale: Alternative for beta-lactam allergy with broad-spectrum coverage

mrsaCoverageAddition.dose: Vancomycin 15-20 mg/kg IV every 8-12 hours + Piperacillin-Tazobactam 3.375 g IV every 6 hours
mrsaCoverageAddition.timing: Immediate initiation
mrsaCoverageAddition.redosingInterval: Vancomycin every 8-12 hours (based on levels), Piperacillin-Tazobactam every 6 hours
mrsaCoverageAddition.rationale: MRSA coverage for high-risk patients or healthcare-associated infection

specialConsiderations: Therapeutic antibiotics, not prophylaxis - this is treatment of established infection
Source control (appendectomy) is mandatory
Duration: 4 days if adequate source control, up to 7 days if complex
Transition to oral antibiotics when tolerating diet and afebrile
Abscess formation: may require percutaneous drainage
Imaging (CT) if no improvement by day 3-4

procedures.name: Perforated Peptic Ulcer (Contaminated)
procedures.description: Emergency surgery for perforated gastric or duodenal ulcer with peritoneal contamination

primaryProphylaxis.dose: Piperacillin-Tazobactam 3.375 g IV or Cefepime 2 g IV + Metronidazole 500 mg IV
primaryProphylaxis.redosingInterval: Piperacillin-Tazobactam every 6 hours, Cefepime every 8 hours, Metronidazole every 8 hours
primaryProphylaxis.rationale: Therapeutic antibiotics for established intra-abdominal infection from gastric/duodenal perforation
warnings: This is therapeutic treatment, not prophylaxis
Consider H. pylori eradication after recovery

betaLactamAllergyAlternative.dose: Ciprofloxacin 400 mg IV every 12 hours + Metronidazole 500 mg IV every 8 hours
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.redosingInterval: Ciprofloxacin every 12 hours, Metronidazole every 8 hours
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.rationale: Alternative for beta-lactam allergy

mrsaCoverageAddition.dose: Vancomycin 15-20 mg/kg IV + Piperacillin-Tazobactam 3.375 g IV
mrsaCoverageAddition.timing: Immediate initiation
mrsaCoverageAddition.redosingInterval: Vancomycin every 8-12 hours, Piperacillin-Tazobactam every 6 hours

specialConsiderations: Therapeutic antibiotics for established infection
Source control: repair with omental patch or resection
Duration: 4-7 days based on clinical response
H. pylori testing and eradication after recovery
PPI therapy essential (IV initially, then oral)
High mortality if delayed treatment

procedures.name: Traumatic Bowel Injury (Contaminated)
procedures.description: Emergency surgery for traumatic bowel perforation with peritoneal contamination

primaryProphylaxis.dose: Cefoxitin 2 g IV or Cefazolin 2 g IV + Metronidazole 500 mg IV
primaryProphylaxis.duration: 24 hours if repair within 12 hours; 4-7 days if delayed repair or significant contamination
primaryProphylaxis.redosingInterval: Cefoxitin every 6 hours, Cefazolin every 8 hours, Metronidazole every 8 hours
primaryProphylaxis.rationale: Early antibiotics reduce infection risk in traumatic bowel injury; duration depends on timing of repair
warnings: If repair within 12 hours: 24-hour prophylaxis sufficient
If delayed >12 hours: therapeutic course (4-7 days)
Assess for other injuries (solid organ, vascular)

betaLactamAllergyAlternative.dose: Ciprofloxacin 400 mg IV every 12 hours + Metronidazole 500 mg IV every 8 hours
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.duration: 24 hours if early repair; 4-7 days if delayed or significant contamination
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.redosingInterval: Ciprofloxacin every 12 hours, Metronidazole every 8 hours
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.rationale: Alternative for beta-lactam allergy

mrsaCoverageAddition.dose: Vancomycin 15 mg/kg IV + Cefazolin 2 g IV + Metronidazole 500 mg IV
mrsaCoverageAddition.timing: Immediate initiation
mrsaCoverageAddition.duration: Based on repair timing and contamination
mrsaCoverageAddition.redosingInterval: Vancomycin every 8-12 hours, Cefazolin every 8 hours, Metronidazole every 8 hours
mrsaCoverageAddition.rationale: MRSA coverage for high-risk trauma patients

specialConsiderations: Timing is critical: repair within 12 hours → 24-hour prophylaxis
Delayed repair (>12 hours) → therapeutic course (4-7 days)
Significant contamination → therapeutic course regardless of timing
Damage control surgery: may require staged repair
High risk of intra-abdominal abscess
Consider antifungal if ICU stay >7 days or recurrent perforation

procedures.name: Necrotizing Soft Tissue Infection (Dirty/Infected)
procedures.description: Emergency surgical debridement for necrotizing fasciitis or gas gangrene

primaryProphylaxis.dose: Vancomycin 15-20 mg/kg IV + Piperacillin-Tazobactam 3.375 g IV + Clindamycin 900 mg IV
primaryProphylaxis.duration: Continue until no further debridement needed, patient improved, and afebrile for 48-72 hours
primaryProphylaxis.redosingInterval: Vancomycin every 8-12 hours, Piperacillin-Tazobactam every 6 hours, Clindamycin every 8 hours
primaryProphylaxis.rationale: Broad-spectrum empiric coverage for polymicrobial infection including MRSA, gram-negatives, and anaerobes; clindamycin inhibits toxin production
warnings: SURGICAL EMERGENCY - immediate debridement is life-saving
Antibiotics are adjunctive - surgery is primary treatment
Consider IVIG for streptococcal toxic shock syndrome
monitoring: Monitor for septic shock and organ failure
Assess wound daily for extent of necrosis

betaLactamAllergyAlternative.dose: Vancomycin 15-20 mg/kg IV + Aztreonam 2 g IV + Metronidazole 500 mg IV + Clindamycin 900 mg IV
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.duration: Continue until no further debridement needed and patient improved
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.redosingInterval: Vancomycin every 8-12 hours, Aztreonam every 8 hours, Metronidazole every 8 hours, Clindamycin every 8 hours
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.rationale: Alternative for beta-lactam allergy with broad coverage
warnings: Complex regimen - ensure all components given
monitoring: Monitor clinical response and organ function

mrsaCoverageAddition.dose: Vancomycin 15-20 mg/kg IV
mrsaCoverageAddition.timing: Immediate
mrsaCoverageAddition.redosingInterval: Every 8-12 hours based on levels

specialConsiderations: SURGICAL EMERGENCY - immediate wide debridement is life-saving
Antibiotics are adjunctive only - surgery is primary treatment
Clindamycin essential: inhibits toxin production in streptococcal/clostridial infections
Repeat debridement often necessary every 24-48 hours until no further necrosis
Type I (polymicrobial): diabetes, immunosuppression, post-surgical
Type II (monomicrobial): Group A Streptococcus, S. aureus - consider IVIG
Hyperbaric oxygen: controversial, may be adjunctive for clostridial infections
High mortality (20-40%) despite aggressive treatment

references.label: IDSA Skin and Soft Tissue Infections Guidelines 2024
WSES Necrotizing Soft Tissue Infections Guidelines 2024

procedures.name: Perforated Diverticulitis (Dirty/Infected)
procedures.description: Emergency surgery for perforated diverticulitis with purulent or fecal peritonitis

primaryProphylaxis.dose: Piperacillin-Tazobactam 3.375 g IV or Meropenem 1 g IV
primaryProphylaxis.duration: 4-7 days therapeutic course, may extend based on clinical response
primaryProphylaxis.redosingInterval: Piperacillin-Tazobactam every 6 hours, Meropenem every 8 hours

warnings: This is therapeutic treatment for established infection
Hinchey III (purulent) vs IV (fecal): both require surgery
Consider antifungal if ICU stay >7 days or recurrent perforation
monitoring: Assess for abscess or anastomotic leak
Monitor for sepsis and organ dysfunction

primaryProphylaxis.dose: Piperacillin-Tazobactam 3.375 g IV or Cefepime 2 g IV + Metronidazole 500 mg IV
primaryProphylaxis.duration: 2-6 weeks therapeutic course based on clinical response and source
primaryProphylaxis.redosingInterval: Piperacillin-Tazobactam every 6 hours, Cefepime every 8 hours, Metronidazole every 8 hours

warnings: This is therapeutic treatment for established infection

monitoring: Monitor chest tube output and character
Monitor for clinical improvement (fever, WBC, CRP)

Culture-directed therapy once organisms identified

procedures.name: Fournier Gangrene (Dirty/Infected)
procedures.description: Life-threatening necrotizing fasciitis of the perineum and genitalia

primaryProphylaxis.dose: Vancomycin 15-20 mg/kg IV + Piperacillin-Tazobactam 3.375 g IV + Clindamycin 900 mg IV
primaryProphylaxis.duration: Continue until no further debridement needed, patient improved, and afebrile for 48-72 hours
primaryProphylaxis.redosingInterval: Vancomycin every 8-12 hours, Piperacillin-Tazobactam every 6 hours, Clindamycin every 8 hours
primaryProphylaxis.rationale: Broad-spectrum coverage for polymicrobial infection (average 4-5 organisms); clindamycin inhibits toxin production
warnings: SURGICAL EMERGENCY - immediate aggressive debridement is life-saving
Antibiotics are adjunctive - surgery is primary treatment
Fecal or urinary diversion may be necessary
monitoring: Monitor for septic shock and multi-organ failure
Assess wound daily for extent of necrosis
Assess for urethral or rectal involvement

betaLactamAllergyAlternative.duration: Continue until no further debridement needed and patient improved
betaLactamAllergyAlternative.redosingInterval: Vancomycin every 8-12 hours, Aztreonam every 8 hours, Metronidazole every 8 hours, Clindamycin every 8 hours

warnings: Complex regimen - ensure all components given
monitoring: Monitor clinical response and organ function

mrsaCoverageAddition.dose: Vancomycin 15-20 mg/kg IV
mrsaCoverageAddition.timing: Immediate
mrsaCoverageAddition.redosingInterval: Every 8-12 hours based on levels

specialConsiderations: SURGICAL EMERGENCY - immediate wide debridement is life-saving
Antibiotics are adjunctive only - surgery is primary treatment
Polymicrobial infection: average 4-5 organisms (aerobes + anaerobes)
Clindamycin essential: inhibits toxin production
Repeat debridement often necessary every 24-48 hours until no further necrosis
Fecal diversion (colostomy) may be necessary if rectal involvement
Urinary diversion (suprapubic catheter) if urethral involvement
Hyperbaric oxygen: controversial, may be adjunctive
Very high mortality (20-50%) despite aggressive treatment
Risk factors: diabetes, immunosuppression, obesity, alcohol abuse
